title: SafeSpeech: Robust and Universal Voice Protection Against Malicious Speech Synthesis
author: Zhisheng Zhang (Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications), Derui Wang (CSIRO's Data61), Qianyi Yang (Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications), Pengyang Huang (Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications), Junhan Pu (Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications), Yuxin Cao (National University of Singapore), Kai Ye (The University of Hong Kong), ..., Yixian Yang (Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications)
relevance_why: The paper introduces novel voice protection techniques that could be highly applicable to audio processing tasks, especially in enhancing the security of audio synthesis systems in Haohe Liu's research.
background: Protecting audio data from unauthorized voice synthesis by embedding imperceptible perturbations to prevent voice cloning.
contribution: SafeSpeech introduces a framework designed to safeguard audio by embedding perturbations that hinder malicious speech synthesis, achieving high effectiveness in preventing identity theft through voice cloning.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous voice protection methods lack robustness against fine-tuning and often generate high-quality deepfake speeches despite applying perturbations.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances protection by utilizing a pivotal objective for perturbation generation that optimizes for both effectiveness and imperceptibility across various text-to-speech models.

key_innovation: Utilizes a surrogate model to generate universal perturbations while ensuring that protected audio retains its usability and does not compromise on quality.
real_world_impact: The framework has potential applications in real-time voice protection against fraud and identity theft in telecommunication, enhancing user security in various applications.
limitations: The authors do not explicitly mention any limitations.

new_terms.Speech PErturbative Concealment (SPEC): **Speech PErturbative Concealment (SPEC)** is a technique that employs perturbations based on Kullback-Leibler divergence to enhance the robustness of audio protection against malicious voice synthesis.

open_sourcing: The source code is available at https://github.com/wxzyd123/SafeSpeech.
